Problem:
Examine a linear system under the transformation \\( z = Hx \\), where \\( x \\) is a vector in \\( \\mathbb{R}^n \\) and H is a constant matrix. This system is further affected by the application of a second function \\( g(z) = e^{Dt}z \\) over time t, where D is also a constant matrix.

If \\( g(z) \\) is applied to a vector \\( z_0 = Hx_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under the transformation \\( z = Hx \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) was directly transformed to t = T under \\( z = Hx \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(z) = e^{Dt}z \\) initially changes the state of \\( z \\) from \\( Hx_0 \\) to \\( e^{Dt}Hx_0 \\), altering the evolution trajectory of the system. Because D could fundamentally interact with H to create a distinct state at any later time T, the path and resulting state of \\( z(t) \\) will differ from not applying \\( g(z) \\).
